verses.text: My son, if you have become surety for your neighbor, if you have given your pledge for a stranger,
verses.comment: The warning here is about making unwise financial commitments on behalf of others, a theme repeated throughout Proverbs.

verses.text: if you are trapped by the words of your mouth, caught by the words of your mouth,
verses.comment: Being ensnared by your own speech underscores the seriousness of making rash promises or oaths.

verses.text: then do this, my son, and save yourself, for you have come into the hand of your neighbor: Go, hurry, and plead earnestly with your neighbor.
verses.comment: Urgency is advised in seeking release from foolish or hasty agreements, a principle of humility and prudence.

verses.text: Do not give sleep to your eyes or slumber to your eyelids;
verses.comment: A call not to delay in addressing the error, emphasizing diligence and responsibility.

verses.text: save yourself like a gazelle from the hunter’s hand, like a bird from the hand of the fowler.
verses.comment: This imagery of escape underscores the danger of foolish binding and the wisdom of seeking freedom from it.

verses.text: Go to the ant, you sluggard; consider its ways, and be wise.
verses.comment: The ant as a model of diligence and foresight calls to mind Christ’s parables of stewardship (see Luke 12:42-48).

verses.text: It has no chief, officer, or ruler,
verses.comment: The ant works industriously without needing external supervision—implying virtue comes from within and is sustained by habit.

verses.text: yet it prepares its food in the summer and gathers its provision at harvest.
verses.comment: Spiritual application: Just as the ant prepares for the future, Christians are called to prepare for eternal life through continual conversion of heart and sacrificial acts.

verses.text: How long will you lie there, O sluggard? When will you arise from your sleep?
verses.comment: A wake-up call, paralleling Paul’s exhortation to awaken from spiritual slumber and live in the light of Christ.

verses.text: A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands to rest—
verses.comment: A repeated proverb, warning of the gradual dangers of habitual laziness.

verses.text: and poverty will come upon you like a robber, and want like an armed man.
verses.comment: The suddenness of ruin is the result of persistent neglect; spiritually, sloth endangers the soul (cf. Matt. 25:26-30).

verses.text: A worthless person, a wicked man, goes about with crooked speech,
verses.comment: The Hebrew word for 'worthless' is related to 'Belial,' denoting utter wickedness—frequently encountered in the wisdom literature.

verses.text: he winks with his eyes, signals with his feet, points with his fingers,
verses.comment: Nonverbal cues used deceptively—an early depiction of how sin pervades both words and actions.

verses.text: with perversity in his heart he devises evil, continually sowing discord.
verses.comment: Discord is seen as an abomination; Christ’s call is to unity—hinting at one faith, one communion (see John 17:21).

verses.text: Therefore calamity will suddenly come upon him; in a moment he will be broken beyond healing.
verses.comment: Divine justice falls swiftly on the evildoer, a warning mirrored throughout Scripture.

verses.text: There are six things the LORD hates, seven that are detestable to him:
verses.comment: A literary device—'six, even seven'—intensifies the solemnity of this list.

verses.text: arrogant eyes, a lying tongue, hands that shed innocent blood,
verses.comment: Echoes of the sixth commandment and the emphasis on humility and truth.

verses.text: a heart that devises wicked plans, feet that are quick to run to evil,
verses.comment: Sin begins in the heart and moves outward, reminding that internal conversion is necessary, not merely exterior observance.

verses.text: a false witness who breathes out lies, and one who sows discord among brothers.
verses.comment: Unity among believers is precious in the eyes of the Lord, a foretaste of the unity willed by the Lord for His followers.

verses.text: My son, keep your father's commandment, and do not forsake your mother's teaching.
verses.comment: Respect for parental instruction points to the wider theme of authority and tradition, foundational for maintaining right belief.

verses.text: Bind them on your heart always; tie them around your neck.
verses.comment: Visual metaphor for internalizing God's law, reminiscent of biblical passages where physical reminders symbolize spiritual realities (cf. Deut. 6:8).

verses.text: When you walk, they will guide you; when you lie down, they will watch over you; and when you awake, they will speak to you.
verses.comment: The formative power of tradition and right teaching, working constantly in the believer’s life.

verses.text: For the commandment is a lamp and teaching a light, and the reproofs of discipline are the way of life,
verses.comment: 'Lamp' and 'light'—symbols of divine wisdom, as Jesus Himself is the true light (cf. John 8:12).

verses.text: to preserve you from the evil woman, from the smooth tongue of the adulteress.
verses.comment: Adultery is here both literal and a symbol for unfaithfulness in religion—paralleling Old Testament imagery for spiritual infidelity.

verses.text: Do not desire her beauty in your heart, nor let her capture you with her eyelashes;
verses.comment: Warning that sin begins internally—desires must be purified, not merely actions restrained. This prefigures Christ’s teaching in Matt. 5:28.

verses.text: for the price of a prostitute is only a loaf of bread, but a married woman hunts down a precious life.
verses.comment: Foolishness in matters of chastity leads to greater ruin; allusions to the pricelessness of the soul.

verses.text: Can a man carry fire in his lap and his clothes not be burned?
verses.comment: Sin’s consequences are inevitable, just as natural law brings inevitable results.

verses.text: Or can a man walk on hot coals and his feet not be scorched?
verses.comment: Another image of unavoidable consequences, foreshadowing the New Testament warnings about spiritual danger.

verses.text: So he who goes in to his neighbor's wife; none who touches her will go unpunished.
verses.comment: Justice is assured for offenses against the sanctity of marriage—seen as a covenant pointing to Christ’s union with His people (Eph. 5:32).

verses.text: People do not despise a thief if he steals to satisfy his hunger when he is starving,
verses.comment: Distinguishes offenses of desperation from those motivated by lust or malice.

verses.text: but if he is caught, he must repay sevenfold; he must give all the goods of his house.
verses.comment: Even necessity does not erase the obligation to make restitution—justice and mercy work together.

verses.text: He who commits adultery with a woman lacks sense; he who does it destroys himself.
verses.comment: The spiritual death accompanying adultery is highlighted—holiness is necessary for seeing God (Heb. 12:14).

verses.text: He will get wounds and dishonor, and his disgrace will not be wiped away.
verses.comment: Earthly consequences of sin persist; the gravity of certain sins is underlined.

verses.text: For jealousy enrages a man, and he will show no mercy in the day of vengeance.
verses.comment: A human parallel to God’s jealous love for His people—righteous zeal for the sanctity of covenant.

verses.text: He will not accept any compensation, nor will he be appeased, though you offer him many gifts.
verses.comment: Some breaches cannot be healed with earthly payment; only true repentance and reconciliation of hearts bring restoration. This is why sins wound not only man, but also require the divine remedy offered by Christ.
